Empowering individuals and communities to recognise, respond, and protect.

Spot the Signs. Take Action. Protect Lives.

What is Safeguarding?

Safeguarding means protecting the health, well-being, and human rights of individuals, especially vulnerable people, to live safely, free from abuse and neglect.

It applies in many settings including schools, healthcare, social care, and communities and involves identifying risks, taking action, and creating safe environments for everyone.

Learn more

Key Principles of Safeguarding

  • Protection – from abuse, harm and neglect
  • Prevention – taking action before harm occurs
  • Accountability – clear roles and responsibilities
  • Empowerment – supporting independence and informed choice
  • Partnership – working with communities and professionals

Who Needs Safeguarding?

  • Children and young people under 18
  • Elderly individuals
  • People with physical or learning disabilities
  • People with mental health conditions
  • Those at risk of exploitation, abuse, or neglect

Safeguarding in Practice

Essential knowledge for creating safe environments and responding effectively to concerns.

How to Recognise Concerns

Recognising concerns means staying alert to changes in behaviour, appearance, or emotional wellbeing. Possible signs of concern include:

  • Unexplained bruises or injuries
  • Withdrawn, anxious, or fearful behaviour
  • Sudden decline in performance or engagement
  • Reluctance to go home or talk about their life outside
  • Overly aggressive or inappropriate behaviour

Safeguarding is everyone's responsibility. If something feels wrong, take action — even subtle signs may indicate a problem.

How to Respond

If someone discloses a concern or you suspect abuse, here’s how to respond responsibly:

  • Stay calm and listen carefully without interrupting
  • Do not ask leading questions or push for details
  • Reassure the person they are doing the right thing
  • Report the concern immediately to the safeguarding lead
  • Record what you’ve seen or heard factually and accurately
  • Never promise to keep things secret if abuse is suspected

Your response can have a significant impact. Always follow your organisation’s safeguarding procedures promptly.

Need to take action or talk to someone?

Report a Concern Get Help

Signs of Abuse

Emotional Abuse

Constant criticism, gaslighting, or isolating someone from friends and family.

Physical Abuse

Hitting, slapping, choking, or any physical harm intended to control or intimidate.

Sexual Abuse

Unwanted touching, coercion, or sexual contact without consent even in relationships.

Financial Abuse

Controlling money, limiting access to finances, or forcing someone into debt.

Coercive Control

Monitoring movements, isolating from support, or using threats to dominate.

Digital Abuse

Spying on messages, tracking location, or controlling online and social activity.

Take the Right Action

Simple steps you can take if you or someone else is at risk

In Immediate Danger

Call 999 or go to the nearest police station or A&E. Emergency services are trained to help.

More on Emergency Help
Talk to Someone

Speak to someone you trust like a friend, GP, teacher, or safeguarding officer.

How to Stay Safe Online

Get Help and Support

  • Police or Ambulance: Call 999
  • 24/7 National Domestic Abuse Helpline: 0808 2000 247
  • Samaritans: 116 123 (free and confidential)
  • Bright Sky App: Free app for finding local support — Download Bright Sky

  • Clare’s Law: Request info on a partner's abusive past
  • DAPOs (Protection Orders)
  • Report abuse via gov.uk
  • Women’s Aid | Men’s Advice Line

If you're concerned about the safety or wellbeing of an adult, you can contact your local Safeguarding Adults Board:

  • Search via the Ann Craft Trust website

  • Mind: mind.org.uk
  • Samaritans: 116 123 | samaritans.org
  • Rethink: rethink.org
  • Childline: 0800 1111 | childline.org.uk

If you’re worried about someone’s safety but want to remain anonymous, you can still report your concerns.

Go to Anonymous Report Form
